question_content.barrons:question: Although he did not consider himself (i)________, he felt that the inconsistencies in her story (ii)_______ a certain degree of incredulity on his part.
question_content.barrons:explanation:
a skeptic; warranted.

Inconsistencies in a story would warrant (justify) disbelief or incredulity on anyone’s part, whether or not he considered himself a skeptic (doubter).

An apostate is incorrect. An apostate is someone who betrays or abandons a former loyalty. The term makes no sense in the context.

A charlatan is incorrect. Charlatans are quacks, persons who pretend to have more skill than they actually possess. The term makes no sense in the context.

Demonstrated is incorrect. Inconsistencies in the woman’s story would not demonstrate (show; prove) incredulity or disbelief on the part of the subject.

Dignified is incorrect. Inconsistencies in the woman’s story would not dignify (elevate; ennoble) incredulity or disbelief on the part of the subject.
